reference: Autor, David, Lawrence F. Katz, and Alan B. Krueger. 1998. Computing Inequality: Have Computers Changed the Labor Market? Quarterly Journal of Economics 113:1169- 1213.

See, for example, (Berman, Bound and Machin, 1998) and (Machin and Van Reenen, 1998).

In net, both raise relative demand for highly skilled workers. Nevertheless, they are conceptually distinct and hold different implications for wage growth. The name Cabot Bank is fictitious. This point is well articulated by (Feldstein, 2000). For an example, see our companion empirical paper to this case, (Autor, Levy and Murnane, 2000).

In addition, to the extent that computers directly substitute for tasks performed by high school graduates, price declines in computer technology place downward pressure on high school graduate wages independent of any employment effects (Autor, Levy, and Murnane, 2000).
